newsitem.title: GABON: Cocoa producers agree individual output targets.
newsitem.headline: Cocoa producers agree individual output targets.

text.p: Cocoa producers agreed individual output targets on Tuesday, rallying round a plan to limit world production over the next three years, Ivory Coast's commodities minister said.
"We have agreed the figures and they are realistic," Guy-Alain Gauze told Reuters on the fringe of a two-day ministerial review in Gabon of the 1993 International Cocoa Agreement.

"Member countries have each set a range of objectives with an average figure meeting the targets," he said. "The figures match World Bank and IMF (International Monetary Fund) recommendations and are realistic," he added.
Gauze is outgoing chairman of the Cocoa Producers' Alliance (CPA) whose ministers were meeting in Gabon's capital on Monday and Tuesday.
The plan envisages cutting total forecast output by 15,000 tonnes in 1996/97, 30,000 tonnes in 1997/98 and 45,000 tonnes in 1998/99.
The 90,000-tonne target was initially agreed at a meeting in September of the International Cocoa Organisation (ICCO), which groups producers and consumers.
Some producers -- Malaysia, Ghana and Brazil -- had objected over differences between their own output projections and CPA projections.
Gauze said the deal, which aims to balance world supply and demand and protect producer economies, would be signed by Tuesday night.
Figures obtained by Reuters showed the following draft output target for CPA members plus a draft world output targets incoprorating projections for non-members Indonesia and Mexico.
Full details of members initial output forecasts and revisions made during talks in Libreville among experts last week and among the ministers were not immediately available.
